Summary: The proposal aims to develop a scalable infrastructure for distributed deep learning by optimizing communication and computation across heterogeneous hardware. It identifies inefficiencies in current frameworks and proposes an adaptive infrastructure with dynamic communication strategies, hardware-aware scheduling, and real-time profiling. The experimental plan includes benchmarking communication strategies, evaluating hardware-aware scheduling, profiling real-world workloads, validating adaptive optimization, and conducting end-to-end scalability tests.
Strengths: Ambitious and intellectually deep hypothesis addressing key inefficiencies in DDL frameworks.
Comprehensive proposed method combining adaptive communication, hardware-aware scheduling, and real-time profiling.
Detailed experimental plan with benchmarks and scalability tests.
Weaknesses: Lack of depth in addressing potential technical challenges, such as integrating multiple communication protocols.
Overhead of real-time profiling and RL-based optimization is not thoroughly discussed.
Experimental plan could benefit from more critical analysis and stress tests.
Risk mitigation strategies are not detailed enough.
Questions: How will the adaptive communication engine handle the complexity of switching between protocols in real-time?
What are the expected overheads of the real-time profiler and RL-based optimization, and how will they be minimized?
How will the hardware-aware scheduler handle extreme heterogeneity (e.g., very old and new GPUs in the same cluster)?
What are the fallback mechanisms if the RL-based dynamic batching fails to converge?
Limitations: Potential high complexity in integrating multiple communication protocols.
Overhead of real-time profiling and RL-based optimization could impact performance.
Scalability might be limited by the heterogeneity of hardware.
RL-based optimization may require significant tuning.
